title: 110_hr2995
content:
The Act is titled the "Small Business Liability Reform Act of 2007" and includes findings. Congress finds that the defects in the civil justice system have a direct impact on interstate commerce by reducing the availability of goods and services. The escalating costs of litigation and unpredictable punitive damage awards have been increasing for the past 30 years. The Supreme Court has acknowledged that excessive punitive damage awards can be unconstitutional. Similarly, holding a party responsible under joint liability can also be excessive in certain situations. Entities, including small businesses, may face unjust costs and increased insurance expenses due to joint and several liability, leading to the need for legislation to address these concerns. Exercise of Congress powers under clauses 3, 9, and 18 of article I of the Constitution and the 14th amendment. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "crime of violence" is defined as in section 16 of title 18, United States Code. The term "drug" refers to any controlled substance not legally prescribed for use by the defendant. "Economic loss" is defined as any pecuniary loss resulting from harm, including loss of earnings, medical expenses, burial costs, and loss of business opportunities, as allowed under applicable State law. The term "person" in this Act refers to any individual, corporation, company, association, firm, partnership, or society. "Harm" is defined as physical injury, illness, disease, death, or property damage. "International terrorism" has the same meaning as in section 2331 of title 18, United States Code. "Noneconomic loss" includes physical or emotional pain, suffering, inconvenience, mental anguish, and other nonpecuniary losses. The term "small business" refers to any unincorporated business, partnership, corporation, association, unit of local government, or organization with fewer than 50 full-time employees. Punitive damages are awarded to punish or deter individuals or entities from engaging in similar behavior in the future. The term "small business" refers to an organization with fewer than 50 full-time employees. The term "State" includes various territories and political subdivisions of the United States. The term "State" includes territories and political subdivisions of the United States. SEC. 4. LIMITATION ON PUNITIVE DAMAGES FOR SMALL BUSINESSES. Punitive damages in civil actions against small businesses can only be awarded if clear and convincing evidence shows conscious indifference to others' rights. SEC. 5. LIMITATION ON JOINT AND SEVERAL LIABILITY FOR NONECONOMIC LOSS FOR SMALL BUSINESSES. In civil actions against small businesses, liability for noneconomic loss is determined based on the percentage of responsibility of each defendant. Each defendant is liable only for the amount of noneconomic loss allocated to them. Separate judgments are rendered against each defendant. In civil actions, liability for noneconomic loss is determined based on each defendant's percentage of responsibility. Defendants are only liable for the allocated amount of noneconomic loss. The trier of fact determines the percentage of responsibility for each person responsible for the harm to the claimant, regardless of party status. Exceptions to limitations on liability are outlined in Section 6. The limitations on liability under sections 4 and 5 do not apply to any defendant whose misconduct involves a crime of violence, an act of international terrorism, liability for damages related to natural resources, or a sexual offense. The limitations on liability do not apply to any defendant whose misconduct involves a sexual offense or a violation of civil rights laws, or if the defendant was under the influence of alcohol or drugs at the time of the incident. This exclusion also applies to false claims or fraud-related actions brought by the United States. SEC. 7. PREEMPTION AND ELECTION OF STATE NONAPPLICABILITY.

This title preempts State laws inconsistent with it. States can choose not to apply this title to actions in State courts involving small businesses if they pass a specific statute.

SEC. 8. EFFECTIVE DATE.

The Act applies to civil actions started after its enactment, regardless of when the harm occurred.
